awd_titl_txt: The Tenth (10th) International GEOS-Chem Meeting (IGC10); Saint Louis, Missouri; June 7-10, 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will provide travel support to students, early career scientists and experimental scientists to attend the 10th International GEOS-Chem Meeting (IGC10) in St. Louis MO on June 7-10, 2022. This meeting brings together scientists, students, and others in the GEOS-Chem modeling community to exchange information that will inform and stimulate fundamental research in the modeling of atmospheric composition with links to climate dynamics, biogeochemistry, and air quality.

GEOS-Chem is an open-source global 3-D model of atmospheric composition used actively by over 160 research groups around the world, including over 50 research groups in US universities. Guidance for model management is provided by a GEOS-Chem Steering Committee including 15 US university professors. International GEOS-Chem meetings have been held every two years and are major events for the global atmospheric chemistry modeling community, with about 250 attendees and a very broad range of topics. Applications of GEOS-Chem span a very wide range of atmospheric composition problems including oxidants, aerosols, carbon gases, stratospheric chemistry, mercury, persistent organic pollutants, and others. GEOS-Chem links with climate and weather models for studies of chemistry-climate-ecosystem interactions, chemical data assimilation, and air quality forecasting. Oral presentations by early-career scientists and graduate students are prioritized at GEOS-Chem meetings, providing for many a first opportunity to present their work in front of a large international audience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project provided travel support for young scientists and keynote speakers to attend the 10th International GEOS-Chem meeting (1GC10) on 6-10 June 2022 at Washington University in St. Louis.  

GEOS-Chem is a global model of atmospheric chemistry managed by a consortium of US universities and used by hundreds of research groups worldwide for a very wide range of applications including air quality, biogeochemical cycling, and climate change.  It is designed as an open-source cutting-edge tool with a nimble approach and low bar to scientific innovation. It emphasizes ease of access and code transparency to encourage development by young scientists. It contributes an atmospheric chemistry simulation capability to US-based meteorology and climate models including the NCAR Community Earth System Model, the Weather Research and Forecasting model, and the NASA Goddard Earth Observing System.

International GEOS-Chem meetings are held every two years as a rallying point for the international user community. IGC10 gathered over 200 participants in person and virtually for scientific presentations on advances in modeling and applications. Keynote speakers provided a broader perspective from outside the GEOS-Chem community. Presentations by young scientists were prioritized, and a young scientists' social together with model clinics were held to foster community and education. 

A major outcome of IGC10 was a blueprint for model development priorities over the next two years.  This arose from meetings of the twelve Working Groups to develop spreadsheets for their indvidual areas.  This organized the model developments implemented in subsequent GEOS-Chem versions. Two years after IGC10, we have been able to implement and benchmark almost all of the model development priorites identified at IGC10.
